In expeditissimis, et efficacissimis paragraphis Pandectarum, totius Juris Romani selectiss[im]is Gemmis: { Ecc&e omnes prudentissima[e], et acutissima[e] Sententia[e] Pragmatica[e], omniu[m] excellentissimorum Jurisconsultorum: cert&e summa a[e]stimatione dignissima[e]: et pra[e]gnatisssimi Fontes Justitia[e] forensis: quicquid nugentur Ciuilium Actionum imperiti Grammatici, et Philologi. Desinant igitur Noui homines, contra fo[e]licissimu[m] Justinianu[m], cert&e prudentissimu[m] Tribonianum queri, de Veteru[m] Jurisconsultoru[m] Romanorum iactura: quorum h&ic existant omnes, aut quasi omnes pra[e]gnantissima[e] Sententia[e] forenses. Nam sicui facta est Iniuria, ills est solis inflicta Vetribus Iurisconsultis, qui immortalem gloriam sperabant &e suis commentarijs: non aut ipsi Jurisprudntia[e], qua[e] in pressiorem, certioremq[ue] redacta est Artis formulam: aut suid, nostrisue posteris, nouis Legu[m] professoribus; qui habent paucis plurima; eaq[ue] certe, et solid&e perstricta, qua[e] pri&us videbantur nimiu[m] vaga, et infinita. Sint literati homines in sua classe, qui Ciuilem Triboniani Industriam satis inciuili temeritate accusant: sed su[n]t in aliena Rep[ublica] nimi&um curiosi, et vltra crepidam no[n] sapiu[n]t nimis. Suidas, vt alijs quibusdam, sic Justiniano, et Triboniano, apert&e iniquuus: Valla, merus Gram[m]aticus, et logoda[e]dalus, in alienas philosophia[e], Jurisq[ue], messes temer&e irrumpens: Viues, in multis nimi&um similis Valla[e]: Antonius Nebrissensis, ieiunus in Jure Lexicographus; nec Legu[m] peritior, qu&a[m] Accursius

marginalia.translation: In the most expeditious and most efficacious paragraphs of the 'Digest' are the most precious jewels of Roman law. Here are all the wisest, most acute statements of pragmatism made by all the most excellent lawyers. Certainly, the statements are the most worthy of the highest praise and the lawyers are the most pregnant sources of public justice. Whatever nonsense ignorent grammaticians and philologians may spout of civil actions. If only the 'new men' would stop complaining about the most happy Justinian and the wisest Tribonianus, about the writings of the old Roman lawyers that they are prepared to throw away. Here are all, or almost all, of their most pregnant public statements. For if wrong has been done to anyone, it has been inflicted only on those old lawyers, who were hoping for immortal glory from their commentaries. And neither to the jurisprudence, which has been skillfully edited into a more concise and more settled shape, nor to their, our, or future new teachers of law, who have the most by the least, and those things certainly and solidly compressed, which previously seemed vague and boundless in the extreme. There may be intellectual types, who accuse the civil industry of Tribonianus of plenty of incivil temerity. But they are too curious about a foreign republic and know nothing more than the soles of their feet. Suda: obviously unfair, thus Justinian and Tribonius. Valla: a mere grammatician and logodaedalus, blundering blindly into the foreign fields of philosophy and law. Viues: in many ways too similar to Valla. CONTINUE.......
